185920300.review: I grew up on Scribblenauts on the DS. Not a lot of content, not a lot of options-- honest to god, not really much of anything. Iteration on this series is what drove it to it's full potential, with Super Scribblenauts and beyond, all the way up to this. I truly think this is the definitive Scribblenauts, and while I hope one day yet another iteration will improve it further, this is a really solid sandbox title.

185285136.review:
Scribblenauts Unlimited is like having a magic notebook where your wildest, most chaotic dreams come true – and then promptly backfire because you spelled "Pterodactyl" wrong. The game lets you summon anything you can spell, from a "Friendly Vampire" to an "Exploding Lobster," making it the most bizarre vocabulary test you'll ever take. Need to cross a river? Summon a "Jetpack." Need to make friends with an angry robot? A "Giant Banana" usually does the trick. It's not just a game; it's an endless spelling bee where creativity reigns supreme, and the dictionary is your best weapon.

But let’s be real, Scribblenauts Unlimited isn’t just fun; it’s secretly teaching you English vocabulary without you even realizing it. Sure, you start out summoning "Dog" or "Car," but before long, you're showing off with "Zeppelin" and "Voracious Kraken." Who knew learning could involve so many unnecessary chainsaws? And the best part? The game doesn’t judge you for using the same three words over and over (hello, "Flying Ninja"), as long as you're having fun. So, whether you're battling evil with a "Laser-Wielding Hippo" or just seeing how many adjectives you can stack on "Taco," Scribblenauts is the perfect blend of chaos and education.

185052166.review:
There isn't much to say about Scribblenauts Unlimited. It's Scribblenauts. If, like me, you have immense nostalgia for playing Scribblenauts on your DS and/or iPod Touch as a kid, you'll get a kick out of this game. That's where the appeal lies though - it's difficult to evaluate this since it was such a blatant nostalgia trip for me.

Objectively, the puzzles are nothing to write home about. An awful lot of them boil down to a character saying something like "Man, I wish I had a horse!", so you write "horse" and win. If you're looking for a puzzle game that's going to be a challenging or rewarding experience, this isn't really much of either. Similarly, it doesn't do anything groundbreaking as a sandbox, either. Yes, you can make a lot of things, but the vast majority of them are just reskins with the same handful of mechanics. This isn't some complex sim where you can mess around with all kinds of interconnected systems. I also kept getting a bug where the game would whitescreen and need to be Alt+F4ed when Alt-Tabbing - in my 6 hours of playtime, it probably occurred 20 times or so. 

All of that said, it's Scribblenauts. If you're looking for a nostalgic trip down memory lane, this will more than deliver. If you don't have fond recollections of playing Scribblenauts as a kid, this is a mediocre and somewhat buggy puzzle/sandbox game that isn't great at being either. If you do, however, you'll have a grand old time with Scribblenauts Unlimited.

6.5/10 - Objectively, this is a simplistic and technically questionable puzzle game, but taken as a nostalgia trip, Scribblenauts Unlimited is a delight.

184066291.review:
It's a fun game that lets you do lots of stuff. You can even use your creativity to spawn things or change characters either to complete the wishes of npcs, or just for fun.

Due to the way the game is made, each map you get into can be turned into a playground for you to do anything you want, or that comes to your mind. You can give weapons to npcs and make npcs fight each other, you can spawn zombies to zombify other npcs, and many more things. You are literally unrestricted about what you can spawn or what adjectives you can give, unless in the case of some special missions, where some npcs can't be added adjectives to.

The way the requests of npcs are done allows you to take broad solutions, either for the best solution ot their problem, or the most stupid or derivative one. For example, a crab creature wanting a house, you can spawn a house for it to it to use the house as its shell, and look very ridiculous. Like seriously, there were many moments where I completed a request with the most ridiculous solution, and ended up bursting in laughter. Beside I also managed to troll a bit on the requests aswell, heh.

And what do you get from doing all the requests in the game done? Well, a huge sandbox you can play with, because the things you can spawn and adjectives you can give to npcs are near limitless. And the best thing is: The state of the stage is saved when you leave, but if you want to reset the stage to play again with it, you can. The game menu allows you to reset the stage to the stage before you begin doing anything, so you can try anything else.

Of course, the game has some problems. One of them is that sometimes you might be unable to do some things, because you have no idea what adjective to type to change the npc. For example, making a npc eat fish. What adjective would one give to make that happen?
Also, some adjectives doesn't make sense, like "Intangible". Intangible literally means you're untouchable, which could mean you could pass through walls and not be hurt by anything. It not only doesn't allow you to pass through walls, but also allow you to be hurt by npcs. It only make you a bit transparent.

The other issue the game has is the skin customization of the player character. By the look is unclear what the buttons does, unless you go trial and error on them. Only later I discovered that clicking a ? button on top-right, and then clicking the buttons will show a tooltip telling what they do.

Anyways, the game is good, even more if you want to unleash your creativity.

184017692.review: I been wanting this game for a while, from seeing DanTDM and my other favorite Youtubers play it as a child. I used to only have Scribblenauts Remix, which was very limited, but now I have this one, and hands down, I've got to say it is one of my favorite puzzle(?) games of all times. The artstyle is unique, kinda reminding me of paper dolls, the story line's twist is original to me, the community made things (for the most part) are radical, the game is addicting, making me come back for more everyday since I've got it. I love all the mythical beings in it(except for mothman and siren, yall did em dirty) , the option to make your own avatar, etc. I just wish that after we beat the game's main storyline, that we could make our own little sandbox worlds, but I know this isn't gonna happen, since this game has been out since the 2010s, and I'm posting this on December 2024, but yeah.

183677625.review:
O Scribblenauts é bom,  mas não vale 90.00R$ reais, eu paguei que não me engane menos de 20R$ na promoção, ou seja, espere uma promoção se você tiver filhos ou até para sua diversão será um bom jogo.

Alguns problemas que vim relatar em minha gameplay- 

1.  Falta de objetos: por ser um jogo mais antigo não existem objetos, como, por exemplo, drone existem muita categoria até algumas que você não vai nem pensar que existe no jogo, mas em minha jogatina sentir falta de alguns objetos ou profissões ou pessoas.

2. Tradução: quando você estiver escrevendo no caderno, vai notar que alguns objetos tem fornas de escrever "estranhas" como roupa de policial, você tem que saber se tá na categoria uniforme, fantasia, roupa ou outra coisa. A mesma coisa se aplica para capacete chapéu, isto vira estressante demais.

3. Missões repetitivas: não tem muito dizer, simplesmente as missões não são marcantes e não puxar sua imaginação e as "missões especiais"

i remembered playing this game as a kid with my family, and i saw it was on sale, so i bought both this and unmasked. i haven't played unmasked yet, but this game is just as fun as i remember it being. the wacky and over the top solutions for each problem is very funny. i played this on the kindle back then, but now i have the steam workshop (i have only spawned scout from tf2 in from it. i fly him around and he cries. it is very funny.) the ost is so incredibly amazing. i listen to it outside the game because it's just such a good and classic soundtrack. the main theme and the track playing at edwin's farm are my favorites personally. it was even better because i got the game 85% off because of a sale, but i think the game is worth the 25 USD is normally costs. lily is adorable, i love her so much.

tldr: please buy this game. it will bring you hours of fun. :thumbs_up:

183596739.review:
Cute and fun, even for grown-ups. There are so many delightful item-world interactions. My partner spawned a zombie and, as we should have expected but didn't, it started turning all the people around it into zombies too. Clever things like that.

Here's another that I still chuckle about 10+ years later: 
I noticed a "Lonely cockroach" in the city map. "Oh, poor little thing. I'll spawn an Attractive Cockroach to be its romantic companion." Of course, to indicate how attractive it was, the Attractive Cockroach looked exactly like the other cockroach, but wearing a tiara. 
A few in-game days later, I returned to the city map. There were now a lot more cockroaches... and half of them were wearing tiaras.

Buy this game! for a kid or a kid-at-heart 😄
